title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: vignette walk apply {gnomeR} functions data AACR Project Genomics Evidence Neoplasia Information Exchange BioPharma Collaborative (GENIE BPC). broad overview AACR Project GENIE BPC can found , details clinical data structure available {genieBPC} package website. purposes vignette, use first publicly available GENIE BPC data release non-small cell lung cancer patients, NSCLC v2.0-public. Note GENIE BPC genomic data unique particular ways: data heterogeneous come multiple genomic panels multiple institutions. Gene aliases across panels may vary. GENIE BPC fusions copy number alterations data may differ common data formats. Differences described Data Formats subsection .

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: gain access GENIE BPC data, please follow instructions {genieBPC} pull_data_synapse() vignette register Synapse account. Synapse account created authenticate using genieBPC::set_synapse_credentials(), ’ll ready pull GENIE BPC clinical genomic data Synapse local environment:
code: library(genieBPC)  # if credentials are not stored in your R environment set_synapse_credentials(username = "username", password = "password") # if credentials are stored in your R environment set_synapse_credentials() #> ✔ You are now connected to 'Synapse' with your Personal Access Token (`SYNAPSE_PAT`) for this R session! #> NULL

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: resulting nsclc_2_0 object nested list datasets, including mutations, fusions, copy number data. nsclc_2_0$NSCLC_v2.0$mutations_extended nsclc_2_0$NSCLC_v2.0$fusions nsclc_2_0$NSCLC_v2.0$cna Note GENIE BPC clinical data available via Synapse, genomic data can accessed via Synapse cBioPortal. Using {cbioportalR} package, users can pull GENIE BPC genomic data directly cBioPortal:
code: # pull NSCLC v2.0-public data from Synapse into the R environment nsclc_2_0 = pull_data_synapse(cohort = "NSCLC",                               version = "v2.0-public") #> ✔ pt_char has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ ca_dx_index has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ ca_dx_non_index has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ ca_drugs has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ prissmm_imaging has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ prissmm_pathology has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ prissmm_md has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ cpt has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ mutations_extended has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ fusions has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" #> ✔ cna has been imported for "NSCLC_v2.0" library(cbioportalR)  # connect to the GENIE instance of cBioPortal cbioportalR::set_cbioportal_db("https://genie.cbioportal.org/api") #> ✔ You are successfully connected! #> ✔ base_url for this R session is now set to "genie.cbioportal.org/api"  # view list of available studies from this instance of the portal # NSCLC v2.0-public is: nsclc_public_genie_bpc available_studies() #> # A tibble: 7 × 13 #>   studyId  name  description publicStudy groups status importDate allSampleCount #>   <chr>    <chr> <chr>       <lgl>       <chr>   <int> <chr>               <int> #> 1 brca_ak… AACR… "Targeted … TRUE        GENIE…      0 2022-10-0…            428 #> 2 glioma_… DFCI… "1,535 gli… TRUE        GENIE…      0 2023-04-1…           1535 #> 3 mbc_gen… Meta… "Breast tu… TRUE        GENIE…      0 2023-04-1…            856 #> 4 nsclc_p… GENI… "NSCLC coh… TRUE        GENIE…      0 2024-02-0…           2004 #> 5 crc_pub… GENI… "CRC cohor… TRUE        GENIE…      0 2024-02-2…           1551 #> 6 erbb2_g… ERBB… "ERBB2 coh… TRUE        GENIE…      0 2024-03-0…            315 #> 7 genie_p… GENI… "GENIE v16… TRUE        GENIE…      0 2024-07-1…         214487 #> # ℹ 5 more variables: readPermission <lgl>, cancerTypeId <chr>, #> #   referenceGenome <chr>, pmid <chr>, citation <chr> # obtain genomic data for GENIE BPC NSCLC v2.0-public mutations_extended_2_0 <- get_mutations_by_study("nsclc_public_genie_bpc") #> ℹ Returning all data for the "nsclc_public_genie_bpc_mutations" molecular profile in the "nsclc_public_genie_bpc" study cna_2_0 <- get_cna_by_study("nsclc_public_genie_bpc") #> ℹ Returning all data for the "nsclc_public_genie_bpc_cna" molecular profile in the "nsclc_public_genie_bpc" study fusions_2_0 <- get_fusions_by_study("nsclc_public_genie_bpc") #> ℹ Returning all data for the "nsclc_public_genie_bpc_structural_variants" molecular profile in the "nsclc_public_genie_bpc" study

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: genomic data GENIE BPC stored Synapse cBioPortal. data structure differs depending genomic data downloaded . Therefore, remainder vignette proceed outlining process annotating genomic data separately genomic data downloaded Synapse genomic data downloaded cBioPortal.

what: Differences Between Synapse and cBioPortal Genomic Data
title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: Please note pulling genomic GENIE data Synapse using pull_data_synapse() pulling GENIE data cBioPortal may result small differences data due systematic differences processing pipelines employed Synapse cBioPortal. differences may include: Data formatting - data sets (e.g. CNA files) may appear wide format Synapse data versus long format cBioPortal data, column attributes names may appear sightly different (e.g. fusions files). Default filtering - default, cBioPortal filters Silent, Intron, IGR, 3’UTR, 5’UTR, 3’Flank 5’Flank, except promoter mutations TERT gene. See cBioPortal documentation details. retained Synapse processing pipelines. Hugo Symbols - genes one accepted Hugo Symbol may referred differently data sources (e.g. NSD3 alias WHSC1L1). tools exist help resolve gene aliases across genomic data sources. See gnomeR::recode_alias(), cbioportal::get_alias() vignettes {gnomeR} {cbioportalR} information use functions work gene aliases.

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: following code chunk uses genieBPC::create_analytic_cohort() create analytic cohort patients diagnosed stage IV NSCLC adenocarcinoma histology. , patients multiple genomic samples, genieBPC::select_unique_ngs() function chooses genomic sample OncoTree code LUAD (available). patients multiple samples OncoTree code LUAD, select metastatic genomic sample. patients multiple metastatic samples OncoTree code LUAD, take latest samples. Note: patients exactly one genomic sample, unique genomic sample returned regardless whether meets argument criteria specified . Create dataframe corresponding panel sample IDs:
code: # create analytic cohort of patients diagnosed with Stage IV adenocarcinoma nsclc_2_0_example <- create_analytic_cohort(   data_synapse = nsclc_2_0$NSCLC_v2.0,   stage_dx = c("Stage IV"),   histology = "Adenocarcinoma" )  # select unique NGS samples for this analytic cohort nsclc_2_0_samples <- select_unique_ngs(   data_cohort = nsclc_2_0_example$cohort_ngs,   oncotree_code = "LUAD",   sample_type = "Metastasis",   min_max_time = "max" ) #> ✔ 63 patients with > 1 next generation sequencing reports were identified #> ✔ 62 of 63 had a unique NGS report selected based on given criteria. #> ! 1 of 63 did not have a unique NGS report selected based on the selected criteria or by having the largest panel, so a NGS report was selected at random (be sure to set a seed for reproducbility!) See `attributes(<your-results>)$random_samples` to view these sample IDs. # specify sample panels and IDs nsclc_2_0_sample_panels <- nsclc_2_0_samples %>%    select(cpt_seq_assay_id, cpt_genie_sample_id) %>%   rename(panel_id = cpt_seq_assay_id,          sample_id = cpt_genie_sample_id) %>%   filter(!is.na(panel_id))

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: create_gene_binary() function takes inputs mutations, fusions, CNA data returns binary matrix alteration status gene, annotating missingness genes included next generation sequencing panel. critical utilize specify_panel argument create_gene_binary(). Samples included GENIE BPC sequenced across multiple sequencing platforms, genes included varying across panels. Without specify_panel argument, missingness correctly annotated, genes tested incorrectly documented altered. Note: can optionally check recode older gene names newer Hugo Symbol data set passing genie option create_gene_binary(recode_aliases=). Using genomic data Synapse: fusions CNA data downloaded Synapse require modifications prior supplied gnomeR::create_gene_binary() function. First, CNA file can transposed match expected input create_gene_binary() using pivot_cna_longer(): Next, fusions file can transposed match expected input create_gene_binary() Finally, reformatted genomic data can supplied create_gene_binary() annotate genomic alterations patients analytic cohort interest. CNA data downloaded cBioPortal includes high level CNA (-2, 2), specify high_level_cna_only = TRUE consistent results based genomic data downloaded cBioPortal. Additionally, use built ’genieoption check gene aliases (see?create_gene_binary` info). Using genomic data cBioPortal: Binary genomic matrices created using genomic data downloaded Synapse cBioPortal equal. proceed using nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_cbio object.
code: # transpose CNA data from Synapse cna_synapse_long <- pivot_cna_longer(nsclc_2_0$NSCLC_v2.0$cna) #> ! Replacing all `.` to `-` in sample_id field (e.g. `P.0001930.T01.IM3` -> `P-0001930-T01-IM3`). #> To prevent this, use argument `clean_sample_ids = FALSE` # transpose fusions data from Synapse fusions_synapse_long <- reformat_fusion(nsclc_2_0$NSCLC_v2.0$fusions) nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_synapse <-   create_gene_binary(     mutation = nsclc_2_0$NSCLC_v2.0$mutations_extended,     cna = cna_synapse_long,     high_level_cna_only = TRUE,     fusion = fusions_synapse_long,     samples = nsclc_2_0_sample_panels$sample_id,     specify_panel = nsclc_2_0_sample_panels,      recode_aliases = "genie"   ) #> Warning: To ensure gene with multiple names/aliases are correctly grouped together, the #> following genes in your dataframe have been recoded (if you are running #> `create_gene_binary()` you can prevent this with `alias_table = FALSE`): #> PARK2 recoded to PRKN #> MRE11A recoded to MRE11 #> RFWD2 recoded to COP1 #> GNB2L1 recoded to RACK1 #> FAM46C recoded to TENT5C #> WHSC1L1 recoded to NSD3 #> C17orf70 recoded to FAAP100 #> PVRL4 recoded to NECTIN4 #> HIST1H3C recoded to H3C3 #> BRE recoded to BABAM2 #> C1orf86 recoded to FAAP20 #> WHSC1 recoded to NSD2 #> HIST1H3B recoded to H3C2 #> TCEB1 recoded to ELOC #> H3F3A recoded to H3-3A #> HIST1H3G recoded to H3C8 #> HIST1H3D recoded to H3C4 #> HIST1H1C recoded to H1-2 #> HIST1H3I recoded to H3C11 #> PAK7 recoded to PAK5 #> HIST1H3E recoded to H3C6 #> HIST1H3H recoded to H3C10 #> HIST1H3F recoded to H3C7 #> FAM175A recoded to ABRAXAS1 #> HIST1H2BD recoded to H2BC5 #> HIST1H3J recoded to H3C12 #> HIST3H3 recoded to H3-4 #> H3F3C recoded to H3-5 #> FAM58A recoded to CCNQ #> H3F3B recoded to H3-3B #> SETD8 recoded to KMT5A #> GPR124 recoded to ADGRA2 #> C11orf30 recoded to EMSY #> WISP3 recoded to CCN6 #> HIST2H3C recoded to H3C14 #> HIST2H3D recoded to H3C13 #> ! 64 columns have all missing values. This may occur when there are genes in your data that are not in the specified panels (see `specify_panel` argument) #> ! 7 `samples` had no alterations found in data sets (See `attr(<your_df>, 'zero_alteration_samples')` to view). These were retained in results as having 0 alterations. nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_cbio <-   create_gene_binary(     mutation = mutations_extended_2_0,     cna = cna_2_0,     fusion = fusions_2_0,     samples = nsclc_2_0_sample_panels$sample_id,     specify_panel = nsclc_2_0_sample_panels,      recode_aliases = "genie"   ) #> Warning: To ensure gene with multiple names/aliases are correctly grouped together, the #> following genes in your dataframe have been recoded (if you are running #> `create_gene_binary()` you can prevent this with `alias_table = FALSE`): #> HIST3H3 recoded to H3-4 #> HIST1H3B recoded to H3C2 #> HIST1H3I recoded to H3C11 #> HIST1H3D recoded to H3C4 #> HIST1H3F recoded to H3C7 #> HIST1H3C recoded to H3C3 #> HIST1H3G recoded to H3C8 #> H3F3C recoded to H3-5 #> HIST1H3E recoded to H3C6 #> HIST1H1C recoded to H1-2 #> H3F3B recoded to H3-3B #> HIST1H3J recoded to H3C12 #> HIST1H2BD recoded to H2BC5 #> H3F3A recoded to H3-3A #> HIST1H3H recoded to H3C10 #> HIST2H3D recoded to H3C13 #> HIST2H3C recoded to H3C14 #> ! 57 columns have all missing values. This may occur when there are genes in your data that are not in the specified panels (see `specify_panel` argument) #> ! 7 `samples` had no alterations found in data sets (See `attr(<your_df>, 'zero_alteration_samples')` to view). These were retained in results as having 0 alterations.

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: can summarize presence alteration event (mutation, amplification, deletion, structural variant) summarize_by_gene() function, gene column captures presence event regardless alteration type. Summarizing first 10 samples KRAS alterations: Using genomic data Synapse:
code: nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_synapse[1:10, ] %>%    select(sample_id, KRAS, KRAS.Amp) %>%   summarize_by_gene() #> # A tibble: 10 × 2 #>    sample_id                KRAS #>    <chr>                   <dbl> #>  1 GENIE-DFCI-005843-1704      0 #>  2 GENIE-DFCI-004022-1313      0 #>  3 GENIE-DFCI-000013-8840      1 #>  4 GENIE-DFCI-000136-6004      1 #>  5 GENIE-DFCI-000215-8010      0 #>  6 GENIE-DFCI-000260-11571     0 #>  7 GENIE-DFCI-000381-9526      0 #>  8 GENIE-DFCI-000410-10003     1 #>  9 GENIE-DFCI-000454-5667      1 #> 10 GENIE-DFCI-000583-11175     0

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: data transformed binary format, can create summaries visualizations better understand data.

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: tbl_genomic() function summarizes frequency alteration events binary data returned create_gene_binary() summarize_by_gene(). Using genomic data Synapse: Summarizing frequencies KEAP1, STK11, SMARCA4 alteration events: Users can subset data set include genes certain prevalence frequency threshold passing function using subset_by_frequency() function. , summarize alteration events >=10% frequency: Using genomic data cBioPortal: Summarizing frequencies KEAP1, STK11, SMARCA4 alteration events: Summarizing alteration events >=10% frequency:
code: nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_synapse %>%    select(sample_id, KEAP1, STK11, SMARCA4) %>%   tbl_genomic() nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_synapse %>%   subset_by_frequency(t = 0.1) %>%   tbl_genomic() nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_cbio %>%   select(sample_id, KEAP1, STK11, SMARCA4) %>%   tbl_genomic() nsclc_2_0_gen_dat_cbio %>%   subset_by_frequency(t = 0.1) %>%   tbl_genomic()

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: can use mutation_viz() function visualize several aspects mutation data, including variant classification, variant type, SNV class top variant genes. purposes vignette visualize genomic data cBioPortal. Using genomic data cBioPortal:
code: mutation_viz_gen_dat_cbio <- mutation_viz(mutations_extended_2_0) #> ! `samples` argument is `NULL`. We will infer your cohort inclusion and resulting data frame will include all samples with at least one alteration in mutation, fusion or cna data frames #> Warning: To ensure gene with multiple names/aliases are correctly grouped together, the #> following genes in your dataframe have been recoded (if you are running #> `create_gene_binary()` you can prevent this with `alias_table = FALSE`): #> HIST3H3 recoded to H3-4 #> HIST1H3B recoded to H3C2 #> HIST1H3I recoded to H3C11 #> HIST1H3D recoded to H3C4 #> HIST1H3F recoded to H3C7 #> HIST1H3C recoded to H3C3 #> HIST1H3G recoded to H3C8 #> H3F3C recoded to H3-5 #> HIST1H3E recoded to H3C6 #> HIST1H1C recoded to H1-2 #> H3F3B recoded to H3-3B #> HIST1H3J recoded to H3C12 #> HIST1H2BD recoded to H2BC5 #> H3F3A recoded to H3-3A #> HIST1H3H recoded to H3C10  mutation_viz_gen_dat_cbio #> $varclass #>  #> $vartype #>  #> $samplevar #>  #> $topgenes #>  #> $genecor

title: Analyzing GENIE BPC Data Using {gnomeR}
text: Additional details regarding GENIE BPC data {genieBPC} R package published following papers: Lavery, J. ., Brown, S., Curry, M. ., Martin, ., Sjoberg, D. D., & Whiting, K. (2023). data processing pipeline AACR project GENIE biopharma collaborative data {genieBPC} R package. Bioinformatics (Oxford, England), 39(1), btac796. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btac796 Lavery, J. ., Lepisto, E. M., Brown, S., Rizvi, H., McCarthy, C., LeNoue-Newton, M., Yu, C., Lee, J., Guo, X., Yu, T., Rudolph, J., Sweeney, S., AACR Project GENIE Consortium, Park, B. H., Warner, J. L., Bedard, P. L., Riely, G., Schrag, D., & Panageas, K. S. (2022). Scalable Quality Assurance Process Curating Oncology Electronic Health Records: Project GENIE Biopharma Collaborative Approach. JCO clinical cancer informatics, 6, e2100105. https://doi.org/10.1200/CCI.21.00105 Technical details regarding proper analysis data can found following publication: Brown, S., Lavery, J. ., Shen, R., Martin, . S., Kehl, K. L., Sweeney, S. M., Lepisto, E. M., Rizvi, H., McCarthy, C. G., Schultz, N., Warner, J. L., Park, B. H., Bedard, P. L., Riely, G. J., Schrag, D., Panageas, K. S., & AACR Project GENIE Consortium (2022). Implications Selection Bias Due Delayed Study Entry Clinical Genomic Studies. JAMA oncology, 8(2), 287–291. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamaoncol.2021.5153 Kehl, K. L., Uno, H., Gusev, ., Groha, S., Brown, S., Lavery, J. ., Schrag, D., & Panageas, K. S. (2023). Elucidating Analytic Bias Due Informative Cohort Entry Cancer Clinico-genomic Datasets. Cancer epidemiology, biomarkers & prevention: publication American Association Cancer Research, cosponsored American Society Preventive Oncology, 32(3), 344–352. https://doi.org/10.1158/1055-9965.EPI-22-0875 Kehl, K. L., Riely, G. J., Lepisto, E. M., Lavery, J. ., Warner, J. L., LeNoue-Newton, M. L., Sweeney, S. M., Rudolph, J. E., Brown, S., Yu, C., Bedard, P. L., Schrag, D., Panageas, K. S., & American Association Cancer Research (AACR) Project Genomics Evidence Neoplasia Information Exchange (GENIE) Consortium (2021). Correlation Surrogate End Points Overall Survival Multi-institutional Clinicogenomic Cohort Patients Non-Small Cell Lung Colorectal Cancer. JAMA network open, 4(7), e2117547. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.17547

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: library(genomeverse) load core genomeverse packages: cbioportalR, pulling data cBioPortal. oncokbR, oncoKB annotation fo data. gnomeR, processing raw mutation, CNA fusion files. also get condensed summary conflicts packages loaded:
